MR. de WILDE: In many respects I think the Japanese
economy has shown in the postwar years a rather impressive
record of accomplishment, and that should always be kept in
mind in an appraisal of the situation. If one looks, for
example, at production, one must take note of the fact that
industrial production in 1952 was about 140 percent of the
normal prewar period, namely, 1934 to 1936, and that in the
first half of 1953 new postwar records in the field of  10
industrial production were set. Agricultural production
perhaps has not soared similarly, but even so agricultural
production is somewhat in excess of prewar levels. In general:
it may be said that per capita production and consumption
in the Japanese economy is about at prewar levels or perhaps
slightly in excess thereof. Moreover, there has been war
damage which was very extensive in Japan, which has been
virtually completely rehabilitated, and the economy has shown
in general in the postwar period a very high rate of investment.
The balance of payments, at least until this year, has
been favorable. In the last three years, from 1950 to 1952,
inclusive, there was a consistent surplus of foreign exchange
reserves over expenditures, which was in excess of $300
million equivalent in each of the last three years. This
has enabled Japan to build up a foreign exchange reserve
of somewheres in the nature of $1 billion, of which well
over $800 million is in gold and dollars.
I think these accomplishments, which are very real, are
all the more remarkable in view of the fact that Japan has
had to contend with enormous difficulties after the war. It
not only suffered very heavy war damage but it suffered very
severe territorial losses, and in the postwar period it
suffered pretty largely the loss of access to the neighboring
Asiatic continent because of developments there and therefore  11
lost virtually all access to markets and sources of supply
i which in 1938, the prewar peak year, had taken about 60
percent of Japanese exports and furnished about 40 percent
of her imports.
Moreover, at present her population of around eighty-Six
million is no less than 19 percent in excess of the prewar
levels, both as a result of repatriation of Japanese from
overseas and the natural growth in the population.
So you see, despite these obstacles there has been a very
impressive postwar record of recovery. This record I think is
. certainly in large measure due to the energy and resourcefulÂ­
ness of the Japanese people, to which Mr. Garner has already
referred. At the same time, I think one should acknowledge
that this record would have been impossible of achievement
if it had not been for the substantial support of the Japanese
economy by the United States. Up to the end of the fiscal
year 1951, this support took the form of Congressional
appropriations for the purchase of supplies, civilian goods,
which were furnished to the economy -- foodstuffs, raw
materials, and so forth. Since the end of the fiscal year
1951 there have been no further direct Congressional
appropriations for the support of the Japanese economy, but
the Japanese economy has continued to earn a very large
amount of foreign exchange from several sources. One of
these sources has been the expenditures of the large amount  12
of U. S. military and also to some extent civilian personnel
in Japan. Another important source has been the procurement
in connection with the Korean war effort, and to a minor
extent procurement in Japan for the mutual security program.
From these sources Japan has derived certainly an enormous
amount of foreign exchange. In 1952 , the revenues from these I : sources which I have alluded to amounted to roughly $800
million, a not inconsiderable sum. In the light of that, one
must, of course, acknowledge that without these sources of
funds accruing to the Japanese economy the Japanese economy
would have shown, letts say, a balance of payments deficit
of roughly a little over $5 0 0 million in 1952, and an actual
deficit with the dollar area of roughly $600 million.
One cannot necessarily presuppose that these revenues
of special dollar income will precipitately decline even now
that the Korean hostilities have come to an end. I think it
is fairly safe to assume that over the next few years they
will still be maintained at a fairly high level. While of
course procurement in connection with the war effort will

I think it is safe to prophecy that there will be a considerÂ­
able continued income from these sources. This, therefore,
